questions.text: Which of the following patients are at risk of developing chronic myeloid leukemia?

choices.text: A middle-aged man whose mother died of chronic myeloid leukemia
An oil-refinery worker with occupational benzene exposure for 20 years
A woman who underwent radiotherapy for carcinoma cervix
An elderly man who received chemotherapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma

questions.solution:
Exposure to a high dose of ionizing radiation is the only known risk factor for developing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This may be in the form of radiation therapy for malignancy or other conditions and nuclear accidents. It is dose-dependent and low-dose radiation exposure is not a risk factor.

There are no familial associations, infections, or toxins associated with the development of CML.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Philadelphia chromosome?

choices.text: Unbalanced translocation between short arm of chromosomes 9 and 22
Unbalanced translocation between long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22
Balanced translocation between short arm of chromosomes 9 and 22
Balanced translocation between long  arm of chromosomes 9 and 22

questions.solution:
Philadelphia chromosome is a balanced translocation between the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22. It is present in the majority of patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

In a balanced translocation, a part of one chromosome is shifted to another chromosome and vice versa. In this case, the ABL gene present in chromosome 9 is translocated next to the BCR gene (breakpoint cluster region) on chromosome 22. It leads to the formation of shortened chromosome 22, which has been named the Philadelphia chromosome after the place of discovery.

questions.text: What is the most common sign in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia?
questions.solution:
Splenomegaly is the most common physical examination finding in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

The majority of the patients with CML are asymptomatic. They are often incidentally diagnosed during routine blood tests when they have elevated white blood cells count. In later stages, the following clinical features develop:

  • Anemia - easy fatigability, exercise intolerance
  • Increased number of WBCs and platelets - hyperviscosity, leading to MI and stroke
  • Increased cell metabolism - night sweats, weight loss, and hyperuricemia (gout)
  • Splenomegaly - abdominal pain, early satiety
  • Hepatomegaly, lymphadenopathy, skin or subcutaneous lesions

questions.text: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score is decreased in patients with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is increased in polycythemia vera and leukemoid reactions.

The biochemical abnormalities in CML include:

  • Low LAP score
  • High levels of:
    • Vitamin B12
    • Uric acid
    • Lactic dehydrogenase
    • Lysozyme

Note: Leukemoid reaction refers to extreme elevations in WBC > 50,000/mm3 due to reactive causes outside the marrow. This includes severe infection, trauma, Down's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Leucocyte Alkaline Phosphatase Score

Alkaline phosphatase activity is found predominantly in mature segmented neutrophils. LAP score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. 

Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP.

questions.text: In patients with chronic myeloid leukemia, which of the following are predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Myelocytes will be predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear of the patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

The clinical hallmark of CML is the uncontrolled production of mature and maturing granulocytes. All of the stages of development of granulocytes can be noted on the peripheral smear in varying numbers:

  • Myeloblast - large cells with a round or oval nucleus, cytoplasm is dark and has no granules
  • Myelocyte - nucleus is oval and is eccentrically placed.
  • Metamyelocyte - nucleus is like a kidney bean-shaped 
  • Band forms - nucleus is in the shape of C or U.
  • Segmented neutrophils- nucleus has 2-5 lobes.

All the cells except the myeloblast have a granular cytoplasm. Due to the varied appearance of the cells, it is called garden party appearance or college girl's appearance.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is found to have the following findings on a routine CBC. A subsequent peripheral smear is performed as shown below. A bone marrow aspiration study is planned for this patient. All of the following are likely to be seen on bone marrow except:

Hemoglobin - 8.4 g/dL

WBC count - 1,65,000/cu.mm

Platelet count - 6,10,000/cu.mm
questions.solution:
The image shows a left-shift with a predominance of segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes that is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Marrow blasts are usually < 5% in the majority of CML patients.

In CML, the following bone marrow findings are noted:

  • Markedly hypercellularity - due to increased granulocytic precursors
    • Myeloid: erythroid ratio (M/E ratio) is significantly increased 
    • Megakaryocytes - normal or increased
    • Erythroid precursors - usually decreased
  • Sea blue histiocytes - macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm.
  • Bone marrow fibrosis may occur due to the deposition of reticulin.
  • Pseudo-Gaucher cells - macrophages with wrinkled tissue paper appearance, as shown below. Due to the increased turnover of the cells, there is an increased accumulation of glucocerebroside within the macrophages.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with easy fatiguability and weight loss. After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia. What is the initial treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of choice in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is tyrosine kinase inhibitors. These include imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib, and ponatinib.

Allogeneic stem cell transplant is considered in patients who are negative for Philadelphia chromosome, or who are non-responsive to the tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

questions.text: A 61-year-old with CML failed to respond to imatinib therapy. Further evaluation revealed a T315I mutation. What drug should he be started on?
questions.solution:
Ponatinib is effective in patients with CML with T315I mutations. It is a third-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

The T315I mutation in BCR-ABL clones is specifically resistant to therapy with imatinib, dasatinib, nilotinib, and bosutinib but is sensitive to the third-generation agent ponatinib. It is also used in the treatment of accelerated and blast phases.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to assess the prognosis in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia?
questions.solution:
Hasford scoring system can be used to assess prognosis in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

The prognosis of CML can be assessed by:

  • Sokal score which is based on:
    • Age
    • Spleen size
    • Platelet count
    • Percentage of blast cells in the blood
  • Hasford score - Similar to Sokal score, but additionally uses the percentage of eosinophils and basophils in the blood

Option A: Rai and Binet staging system is used for staging chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

Option B: Ann Arbor staging system is used in Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas.

Option D: Matutes scoring system is used for the diagnosis of CLL by flow cytometry.

questions.text:
All of the following patients with chronic myeloid leukemia are in the accelerated phase except:
  Peripheral blast cell count     Peripheral basophil count    
Patient 1         20%      15%
Patient 2         10%      25%
Patient 3         13%      21%
Patient 4         15%      14%
questions.solution:
A blast count ≥ 20% in peripheral blood is indicative of a blast crisis, not the accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

CML can be divided into three phases:

  • Chronic stable phase - Blasts < 10% in peripheral blood and bone marrow
  • Accelerated phase - any of the following:
    • Blasts comprising 10-19% of white blood cells (WBCs) in peripheral blood and/or bone marrow
    • Peripheral blood basophils ≥20%
    • Thrombocytopenia or thrombocytosis not responsive to therapy
    • Additional cytogenetic abnormalities in Philadelphia chromosome cells
  • Blast crisis:
    • Blasts ≥ 20% of peripheral blood WBCs or bone marrow
    • Extramedullary blast proliferation

Majority of the patients present in the chronic stable phase. Without effective treatment, CML in the chronic phase will eventually move into an accelerated phase at first and then into the blast phase.

While the accelerated phase was an aggressive form of CML, the benefit of tyrosine kinase inhibitors and disease monitoring has successfully led to the omission of the accelerated phase of CML as per the 5th edition of the WHO classification of hematolymphoid tumors.

questions.text: What is the classical immunophenotypic picture seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia?
questions.solution:
The classical immunophenotypic feature seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is CD19+, CD20+, CD21+,CD22+, CD23+, CD5+. It is significant for coexpression of the B cell marker CD19 with the T cell marker CD5. 

Mantle cell lymphoma has the same immunophenotype but with absent CD23.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with fever is found to have a WBC count of 1,50,000/cu.mm. His peripheral smear study is given below. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: It arises from the  myeloid lineage
Radiation exposure is a risk factor
It arises from the T lymphocytes
Patient may have autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.solution:
The smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and the presence of a smudge cell. The most probable diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Patients with CLL may have autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA).

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia/ small lymphocytic lymphoma refers to the monoclonal proliferation of mature B lymphocytes. It is more common in men than women. Increasing age and family history are important risk factors. CLL is one of the few leukemias not linked to radiation exposure.

The majority of the patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed during routine blood tests. Some patients may have painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Increased B cells may produce autoantibodies leading to autoimmune complications like autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP).

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 71-year-old asymptomatic woman diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia?
questions.solution:
Expectant management is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). This is because there is no clear survival benefit with chemotherapy in asymptomatic patients.

Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodies are used in the presence of the following features:

  • Progressive marrow failure - worsening anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • Progressive splenomegaly
  • Progressive lymphadenopathy
  • Presence of constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fever, night sweats

Important drugs used in the management of CLL are fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, bendamustine, and rituximab.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Richter syndrome?
questions.solution:
Richter's syndrome is the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It has a poor prognosis.

Patients develop the following features:

  • Fever, and weight loss
  • Rapidly enlarging lymph nodes 
  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase
